Everyone agrees on pipelining, but there is significant doubts from everyone except you and maybe terence about the implications (complexity, market structure, will it be used, etc) of builder payments.
ï»¿
> people are still trying to enshrine relays and remove builders altogether
You are correct, not changing payment structure would keep MEV-Boost in the block-building pipeline. But this is separate to the core pipelining improvement that everyone agrees on. Builder payments as an additional feature (separate EIP) need to be debated separately as it is widely agreed this is not strictly necessary for pipelining (it is an add on with some benefits for some potential users, but not all), adds complexity, and has implications that have not been properly understood by core devs (who are delegating decision making to you and terence it seems).
ï»¿
Why are we risking another collapse in governance ? Take the pipelining benefits when they have ~100% agreement (free option can be addressed later). I can only speak for myself, but failure to listen to a majority of opinion holders on this will hurt the trust and effectiveness of the EIP process going forward.
ï»¿
> people are still trying to enshrine relays and remove builders altogether
Circling back on statements like this. Although this might have knee-jerk appeal to core devs on the fence, the implication that block-building pipeline experts outside of core devs are trying to erode core values, or anything like that, is incorrect. The goal here is separate 7732 into its two components of pipelining and payments, include the pipelining which everyone agrees on, and debate the payments when people have time to properly understand, analyse and consider them.

author: potuz
content: All I keep reading in statements like these is that no one agreed on EIP-7732, instead they agreed on this other inexistent EIP, with no design, but that it is much simpler than EIP-7732 and achieves the same pipelining. We should not break the EIP-process and try to please agree on shipping this other inexistent EIP, that removes a lot of the complexity of 7732.  There is an implicit assumption that EIP-7732 is modular and there are two independent components that are clearly marked "pipelining" + "trusteless payments", and that removing the latter is as trivial as just removing that module in the EIP, which is a strict removal of complexity and therefore it will be faster to ship. Moreover, the only argument I hear is this "we haven't agreed on EIP-7732 at all" instead of even trying to make a case for the removal of this module of "trustless payments" that is so bad that we do not want it even if "trusted payments" are already allowed and may be the default. Anyway, I find it insulting to the process to hint that  "I am risking the collapse in governance" when the option is to have ACD drop an SFI'd EIP for another one without an existing design. Such choice in the name of simplicity and speed of delivery is even more laughable, since clearly we'll be delayed until that design even appears.

author: fradamt
content: I am not arguing for this, but just for the record, the alternative design can just be "don't do anything to guarantee/process the payment and instead assume it keeps happening off-band", i.e. remove `BuilderPendingPayment` and `BuilderPendingWithdrawal` and any related processing, do not merge the remaining fork-choice changes that are exclusively about giving guarantees to the builder in case of equivocations. I also do not understand at all the argument that staked builders can't just easily be removed. The bid can be left unsigned since it's not travelling through p2p and since the signature doesn't give you any payment guarantee at that point. I don't think removing this stuff from the existing spec would be particularly hard. However at this point I think it's unlikely that it is going to make things faster, maybe the opposite.

author: fradamt
content: Personally the main reason I would have preferred to do just the pipelining stuff (which is definitely doable on its own) is that trustless payments seem like a nice fallback but coming with some annoying extra complexity  (staked builders, more withdrawal machinery, more small fork-choice tweaks) and with quite unclear future-compatibility consequences, because it's not a fallback that it's easy to support. For example, it likely means that future consensus designs need to either compromise on adversarial resilience (we don't care in the current protocol because it is what it is anyway) or on latency. It also means we have less freedom to re-organize block production/the slot, because the design space is going to be restricted to what can support this feature.

author: fradamt
content: Is this a conscious choice we're making, fully aware of the tradeoffs? No, definitely not. Are we going to be willing to reassess this in the future based on a more mature understanding of the tradeoffs? No, probably not. Once the feature exists, it's extremely unlikely that it is going to be acceptable to go in a different direction that is not able to support it. Even if we were to rebuild the consensus protocol from the ground up, it is going to be subject to the constraints created by needing to support this feature

author: fradamt
content: Also just as a retrospective, the reason an alternative design does not exist other than in words (as in an alternative EIP, specs) is  imo in large part due to the fact that at every step this has been a very charged, contentious topic, and everyone that has been involved in it is tired of it

author: fradamt
content: That said, it is a nice feature (seen as a fallback, which is what is actually useful imo) which can hopefully make the network a bit more resilient to certain specific failure modes and perhaps even help us move away from the lowest-common-denominator local block building. It's entirely possible that doing a bit of extra work and stomaching a bit of extra complexity is well worth it. I would feel much better about it if it wasn't a forever commitment though, but that's just not how things go

author: potuz
content:
yes, there are a few alternative designs: 
- With relays, mev boost, proposer signs everything and has two roundtrips to sign both payload envelope and CL block
- With protocol builders signing the payload, remove the pending payments and withrawals logic from the protocol, but keep the staked builders to have their BLS keys. 
- Several variations of the above design, with minimally staked builders that are not validating, with regular validators, etc. 

All these designs are valid, they achieve pipelining and have different tradeoffs from the current design, which is fully written.

author: barnabemonnot
content:
fwiw I think it's less a failure of governance than a failure of having this alternative pipelining-only design written, spec'd and championed. I really appreciate the efforts of <@911437720994324570> in that direction, I think more should have been done earlier to really get us to a point where we can evaluate just how much implementation complexity could have been removed and to have a fair discussion on which features of 7732 were consensus and which were not.

I also think it's fair to say that we can imagine pretty well what such a design would look like, and imo it's been overstated just how much of an unknown it really is (Lin did spec some of it, though different from what I think would have been preferred, i.e., with the proposer committing to the exec payload in the beacon block, but that's minor).

Barring the presence of this alternative it does seem preferable to me for 7732 to proceed as is, but I agree with Francesco that we'll likely regret the protocol complexity that is being introduced.

> i.e., with the proposer committing to the exec payload in the beacon block, b
So I guess you'd go the route of 

- Proposer requests bids from the relay/builder. 
- Bids contain a hash of the payload. Proposer signs block with the commitment. And broadcasts CL block. 
- Proposer requests blinded payload envelope from the builder/relay. 
- Proposer signs blinded payload envelope and returns it to the builder/relay. 
- Builder/Relay assembles full payload and broadcast.

> The bid can be left unsigned since it's not travelling through p2p and since the signature doesn't give you any payment guarantee at that point. 
Yes, but you can't really do that with the approach of "just removing the builder payments and withdrawals" since the proposer can just inlcude bogus bids from builders and this may end up with blacklistings or whatever.  It doesn't make any sense to remove the signature from bids but keep them on the payload envelope (to avoid the extra blind rountrip). If you were to also remove the signature from the payload envelope and rely on blind signing then yes, it doesn't make sense to sign the bids as well.  I fully agree that having the full mechanism as today with staked builders but without any payment mechanism is viable though, as in option 2 in the list above.
